PRESIDENT'S ADDRESS

 

Debate on the Address

(2nd Allotted Day)

 

     Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [17th January, 2005],

 

     'That the following Address in reply to the Speech of the President be agreed to:-

 

     "We, the Parliament of the Republic of Singapore, express our thanks to the President for the Speech which he delivered on behalf of the Government at the Opening of the Second Session of this Parliament.".' - [Mr Gan Kim Yong].

 

     Question again proposed.

     Dr Loo Choon Yong (Nominated Member): Mr Speaker, Sir, thank you for allowing me to join in the debate on the Motion of Thanks on the President's Address at the Opening of this Session of Parliament.

 

     In his Address, the President said, "We must strengthen our economy.  A thriving economy will provide us the resources to tackle all other challenges."  I support this policy direction and commend the Government's intention to maintain a pro business strategy, keeping taxes low and Government trim.  I agree that, in this way, we will encourage more Singaporeans to become entrepreneurs, to dream dreams, develop new ideas and pursue their passion.  When they succeed, they will create more jobs for other

Column: 198

Singaporeans and add to the wealth of our nation.

 

More conducive environment for entrepreneurship

 

     I am glad to note that we are moving away from our old habit of "picking winners".  Singapore needs entrepreneurs of all types, big ones, small ones, low tech as well as high tech.  Studies have shown that economies with greater entrepreneurship experience higher growth rates, greater job creation and less severe boom and bust economic cycles.  Entrepreneurship in Singapore is generally not entrepreneurship of necessity, but entrepreneurship of creativity and innovation.  As the environment becomes more conducive, the threshold will be lowered for people to strike out on their own, try their hands at business. Our society will in the process also become enlivened and more vibrant.

 

     I believe that Singapore is becoming more entrepreneurial as a society because both the people and the Government have made the necessary mindset shift.  Although these are early days, the situation looks promising.  I hope we will be able to have some measurable outcome in due course.

 

Towards a sustainable economy

 

     Despite our economic progress in the last 40 years of nationhood, there is a nagging fear that our economic growth may not be sufficiently robust to withstand prolonged recession, international terrorism, unexpected calamities or unforeseen epidemics.  Not everybody believes that we have a robust and sustainable economy.  With our reserves, many people know that we can pump ourselves out of any cyclical downturn, but what if any of these terrible eventualities befall us?  Such a fear will

Column: 199

surely erode and undermine the confidence and trust our people have in Singapore.  It will also weaken our resolve and loosen the roots that bind us to our motherland.

 

     To remain firmly rooted in Singapore, we must be convinced that our small population of four million multi-racial and multi-cultural people is capable of being developed into a sustainable economy, and an inclusive society which recognises different talents, abilities and needs, where we will all have a place.

 

Possible lessons from Nordic economies

 

     In this regard, I believe the Nordic economies and Switzerland offer interesting lessons.  They are, like us, small countries with small population:  Sweden, 9 million; Norway, 4.6 million; Finland, 5.2 million; Denmark, 5.4 million; and Switzerland, 7.5 million.  I think the annexures have been circulated for easy reference.  They may have bigger land area but they also have harsh climatic conditions.  It is true that Norway has struck oil but it appears that the reserves may last them, at best, another 20 years.

 

     They are all highly developed countries in terms of physical infrastructure.  Their people enjoy high standard of living.  Their per capita GDP ranges between US$26,800 (Sweden) and US$32,700 (Switzerland).  Their people are highly educated, highly skilled and their workers' productivity is high.  They pay high taxes, but they are also progressively lightening their taxes to be competitive.  Their cost of living and cost of doing business are high, like ourselves. But what is noteworthy is that despite being small like us, burdened with some of the same constraints we have, they have been able to register sustainable economic growth over a long period. 

 

Impressive sustainable growth

 

     Between 1913 and 1998, a period of 85 years, their GDP has grown by many-

Column: 200

fold:  Norway, 17.1 times; Finland, 14.8 times; Sweden, 9.5 times; Switzerland, 9.2 times; and Denmark, 11.3 times.  It is even more remarkable when you consider that this period included the disruptions of the Second World War and, in the case of Finland, the regular "push and shove" of their Soviet bear neighbour.

 

     Since these economies have shown such sustainability, perhaps we should take a closer look at their economies and societies to see if there are useful lessons for us.  Perhaps the MTI could form a small task force to look into this matter, and should we find useful tips, we should consider introducing the same to our economy.

 

Some discerning features

 

     Not being an economist by training, and having only one part-time assistant, we got whatever data we could find and try to make sense out of it.  Interestingly, there are a few discernable features in these countries. 

 

     First, if you look at their R&D expenditure as a percentage of their GDP, you will find that Sweden spends 4.27%; Finland, 3.46%; Denmark, 2.52%; Switzerland, 2.57%.  By comparison, our R&D expenditure in Singapore was 2.13% for 2003.  So we are spending less than them.

 

     Second, industries, ie, private sector, in these countries undertook a larger proportion of the R&D compared to Singapore.  In Sweden, the private sector undertook 77.6% of the R&D effort; Switzerland, 73.9%; and Finland, 71.1%.  Our corresponding figure in Singapore was 63.3%, 10 percentage points lower.

 

     It is believed that when industries are encouraged to invest more in R&D, the economic impact and returns from such

Column: 201

R&D activities are more tangible, and they result in economic growth.

 

     Third, the literacy rates in these countries are all about 100% - one or two countries, 99% - whilst ours is 94.2%.  Moreover, what is particularly impressive is that these countries generally have higher percentage of people who receive tertiary education and, consequently, a larger proportion of their workers have got longer years of education, and increasingly so.  In Denmark, 39% of their people have got higher education; Finland, 41%; Sweden, 30%.  In Singapore, our corresponding figures, including the diploma and degree holders, add up to 22.8%.  So we still have some way to go to ensure that our workforce is even better educated.

 

Finding the critical success factors for Singapore

 

     Besides investments in R&D and a responsive educational system that produces a well educated and well trained workforce, I believe there could be other critical success factors for durability and sustainability of the economies in these countries.  These economies have produced today's Volvo cars and trucks, Saab cabriolets and planes, Astra pharmaceuticals, Nokia phones, Electrolux fridges and washing machines, Borfos and Oerlikon guns as well Rolexes, Swatches, Frank Mullers and other timepieces, whose names many of us cannot pronounce.

 

     I hope the Government will continue to review and, if necessary, restructure our economy and take whatever steps necessary to ensure that our economy will remain robust and capable of sustainable growth, so that Singapore will become the home for our children and our children's children.

 

Column: 202

    We Singaporeans have demonstrated through past recessions, the 911 crisis and SARS outbreak that we will rally behind the Government and stand ready to make the necessary changes to strengthen our economy and build a secure future.

 

     I am reassured by the following words in the President's Address:  "We must ensure that all Singaporeans benefit from our success as a nation. ...  Therefore, no group should miss out on the fruits of our progress. ...  We must help to uplift children from lower income families and others less well endowed, so that they can succeed in school and in their careers, and so break the cycle of poverty."

 

     These are beautiful words, great words, and they paint the vision that gives life and meaning to and ennoble our quest to build a stronger, more robust and more resilient economy.  This is the solemn promise the Government under the leadership of Mr Lee Hsien Loong has pledged.  We look towards the realisation of this vision.  Singapore will then truly be a land of opportunity for all.

 

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Sir, the President said:

 

     "The people are entitled to demand the best from their leaders.  They also aspire to play a part, and expect to do so. Everyone who makes Singapore home will have opportunities to make a difference.  Every contribution is valued and important.  There will be unforeseen challenges, but so long as we stay united we will overcome them."

 

These are stirring words and I concur with the President, and hope that something can materialise as far as the Opposition is concerned. 

 

     In 2002, in that policy statement, the President said:

 

Column: 203

     "In politics, we must

remake our policies to fit a new generation of Singaporeans and adapt our style and approach to stay in tune with the times.  No policy is so cast in stone that it can never be changed, whatever the circumstances."

 

     Since 2002, nothing significant has changed.  The political situation remains the same - strict, harsh and threatening.  Basically, all the strict laws, rules and regulations are still intact except maybe the revocation of the necessity to register with the Police to speak at the Speakers' Corner, otherwise, nothing has changed.  There is a slight concession and it has no important significance because the popularity of the Speakers' Corner has not improved.  The number of people wanting to speak at the Speakers' Corner has not increased.  The Opposition was hoping for some form of glasnost to happen in Singapore, but nothing of that sort took place at all.  Singapore is still a closed society as far as Opposition activities are concerned, despite the encouraging pronouncements by the Government. 

 

     The most feared piece of legislation in Singapore today is the Internal Security Act, or ISA.  Under that law, the Government can exercise its administrative powers on any person in Singapore.  A person can be detained without trial for a period of two years and that period is renewable at the end of every two years.  This draconian law hangs like a huge sword of Damocles over the head of every citizen in Singapore.  This law which allows detention without trial can be very easily implemented.  It needs only the signature of the Minister for Law.  That was the way the French citizens court operated during the French Revolution in 1783 - only one signature. 

 

     The nature of the ISA is entirely political.  That is why there is so much widespread fear in Singapore even up to today.  I will give an illustration. Two weeks ago, at the meet-the-people

Column: 204

session, three university students came to visit me, and I asked them to write their names and addresses on a piece of paper so that I know who I am talking to.  But one of them was so afraid that he did not even want to give his name and address to me, an Opposition Member.  Even university students who are supposed to be educated and know better are in fear of associating with the Opposition.  So the fear in Singapore is quite real. 

 

     If Singapore wants to be a lively, vibrant and dynamic society, then the element of fear upon its citizens must first be removed.  As a first step, I call for the removal of the ISA.  I have done this once before in this House.  I now do it again.  The ISA must be repealed.  Its presence is incongruous with modern day Singapore, especially when Singapore wants to remake itself.  Some might argue that the ISA can be used to combat the terrorists.  Indeed, the Government has used the ISA against members of the Jemaah Islamiyah in Singapore.  In the case of other countries, like England, where it had been fighting terrorists, in particular the IRA for many years, anti-terrorist laws are used to combat the IRA.  Under the anti-terrorist laws, when terrorists are apprehended, they are tried in a proper court of law under the Anti-terrorist Act.  And that law has proven to be very effective in England.  The IRA has finally entered into some form of truce with the Northern Ireland government. 

 

     Singapore can do the same.  The Government can quickly enact anti-terrorist laws and when they are legislated and in place, the ISA can be repealed.  I am surprised that the Remaking of Singapore Committee did not assign to itself the duty to recommend to the Government to repeal the ISA.  I believe that the time is ripe for the repeal of the ISA and suitable anti-terrorist laws enacted in its place. 

 

     I wish now to speak on the Opposition in Singapore.  I believe that the PAP's

Column: 205

disdain for the Opposition is historical.  The PAP was advised by Dr Albert Winsemius, amongst other things, in its development plan for Singapore, to crush the communists.  Dr Winsemius, by the way, was a Dutch professor, invited by the World Bank to advise the Singapore Government in the early 1960s.  The PAP did successfully crush the communists.  The PAP did the job so well that it became a reflex action and went also against all other legitimate political parties that opposed it.  The Opposition parties were so depleted that, even today, it has not taken root in Singapore.  All Opposition parties in Singapore are of course legally registered and work within the framework of the law.  But, nevertheless, when the PAP fights, it goes for the jugular. 

 

     All political parties must have the benefit of the three elements to exist successfully: (1) the organisation of propaganda; (2) the selection of candidates; (3) the financing of capital.  Needless to say, the PAP has arranged in Singapore that it has the complete benefit of all the three elements.  But the Opposition parties are completely deprived of them.  On top of the said three elements, there is still the element of fear which exists in the people of Singapore.  They are fearful that something bad may befall them if they go against the Government.  This perception of fear may or may not be there but the Government from time to time keeps it alive by threatening not to provide public facilities if a constituency votes against them.  Come to think of it, it is really a miracle that, under these harsh circumstances, two Opposition Members can be elected  to Parliament.  I attribute it to the bravery and resilience of the people of Singapore!  That is why Singapore is so great.

 

     I would like to speak now a little about the election.  First of all, I would like to

Column: 206

say that the system of election in Singapore is unfair to the Opposition.  Two general elections ago, there were 22 single seats but, today, there are only nine single seats.  The number of single seats may be further whittled down in this coming general election.  At first, the number of the GRC seats was suggested at two or three.  But today, the number of GRC seats in each of the mega constituencies comprises five and six.  The election deposit, at one time, was only a few hundred dollars.  But at the last election, it was increased to $13,000 per candidate.  And with the passing of the Political Donations Act, whereby all political parties have to report the particulars of donors above the first sum of $5,000 donation, it makes it very difficult or almost impossible for the Opposition parties to raise campaign funds.

 

    Opposition campaigns are often deprived of choice of rally sites during the short nine-day campaign.  Rally sites have been drastically cut down, only one per constituency, although there is more than one candidate in that constituency.  The list of complaints can go on.  But above all, I say that for modern Singapore, where citizens are made to believe in meritocracy, the idea of the GRC is absolutely archaic and out of place.  It demeans the minority or ethnic community in Singapore.  I do not believe that Singaporeans are so racist that in time to come, Chinese Singaporeans will only vote for only Chinese candidates and that a Malay or an Indian candidate can never get elected to Parliament. 

 

 

     Mr Speaker: Mr Chiam, I hope all this has somehow got to do with the President's Address.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Yes.  When Singaporeans in the past were allowed a free vote, they voted a Jew to the first post of Chief Minister, which was

Column: 207

equivalent to Prime Minister in the present day.  In 1981, an Indian opposition was voted in in Anson to break the PAP monopoly in Parliament.  In the not-too-distant past, when there were only single-seat constituencies, Parliament was filled with sufficient representative numbers of Eurasian, Malay and Indian Members.  In fact, I have been in Parliament long enough to have met many of them and have fond memories of them, especially Mr Eddie Barker, a Eurasian, the then Minister for Law.

 

     GRCs are not only undemocratic but also communal in nature.  At every election, the ethnic member has to appear before a race committee to certify that he is in fact an Indian, a Malay or other.  If I were an Indian or a Malay, I shall object to that screening process.  Anyone who is a Singapore citizen and is not barred by the conditions of the Constitution should qualify to stand as a candidate in any election.  Why should the Singapore citizen, on top of his initial qualification and citizen, prove that he is an Indian or a Malay?  The GRCs, I say, must be scrapped. 

     Dr Wang Kai Yuen (Bukit Timah): Mr Speaker, Sir,  I would like to join the House in thanking the President for a speech that sets the Government's priorities in the coming years.  I like the framework presented - the seven priorities of the Government.  To me, Singapore's place in the world and a secure environment form the foundation for this particular framework.  Quite unlike Mr Chiam, who spoke about the ISA and wants to repeal the ISA, I personally feel that the ISA is one of the pieces of legislation that forms the basis to ensure the continued security of Singapore. 

 

     The President moved on to talk about

the need to build the economy and the need to educate and train our people.  These two priorities are the building blocks of the economic well-being of our

Column: 208

citizens.  Following this, the President's focus shifted to balancing material aspirations versus emphasis on family, engaging our youth and ensuring everyone in Singapore would benefit from the progress of our nation as the ultimate goal of being Singaporeans.  This framework, focusing on Singaporeans as individuals and as a community, is inspiring.  It reiterates that, under Prime Minister Lee, the role of the Government would no longer be primarily focused on economic development but also, ultimately, on social and community development.  Economic development is just an enabler, not the final destination.  It suggests that the end objective of the progress of our nation is the development of each individual as a more holistic and wholesome individual.  It envisions that working as a community, Singapore would be a more people-oriented nation, with warm-hearted people, caring and supportive, happy and self-assured.

 

     Sir, I find this vision appealing.  In pursuit of the better standard of living, Singaporeans have been perceived to tilt towards the materialistic side.  We ourselves have listed the five Cs as our pursuits.  We coined the phrase "the Ugly Singaporean" to describe our behaviour outside Singapore, as some of us reverted to our old selves once we are outside the constraints of the rules and regulations of Singapore.  Our people were condescending to the residents of our poorer neighbours.  We have a sense of superiority towards new immigrants from the very same countries, such as China and India, where our forefathers migrated from.  In particular, the local Chinese press almost enjoyed playing up the negative aspects of visitors from China, such as peidu mamas, KTV hostesses, making it even more difficult for the authorities to relax entry requirements for Chinese visitors and tourists.

 

     Sir, the recession, as well as the downturn caused by SARS in 2003,

Column: 209

mellowed us.  The recession taught us that we are not invincible as a country, as an Asian tiger.  SARS taught us that the world is an inter-linked one.  Furthermore, two tragic events demonstrated that, despite our own problems and anxiety about our future, Singaporeans have retained our love and compassion for our fellow beings.  One, a small one, Huang Na's tragic death, touched the hearts of many Singaporeans.  But it was the Indian Ocean tsunami on 26th December 2004 that buttressed my faith in Singaporeans as a people.  When the tsunami struck, I was in Sichuan, China, attending an investment promotion conference.  There, the news hardly made a ripple.  Maybe Sichuan was too far away from the sea.  Maybe the impact was not felt yet.  When I returned to Singapore on 30th December 2004, the tsunami relief programme put in place by the Government was already moving into high gear.  Private donations, both in kind and cash, were pouring in.  The contrast was stark.  The selfless outpouring of compassion towards the tsunami victims by Singaporeans was indeed heart-warming to witness.  I got a first-hand experience when the Bukit Timah grassroots volunteered to raise funds for the Red Cross at the market and IMM on 2nd January 2005.  Young or old, rich or poor, the generosity of Singaporeans is touching.  While Singaporeans are still very much worried about our future, the tsunami has taught us that our problems are minor ones.  It has taught us that ours is a blessed land.  More important than the physical attributes of our small island, Singapore is a blessed country because of our people.  As the political leader, Prime Minister Lee could not have a better people than Singaporeans to work with, to mould into the nation as envisioned in the President's Address.

 

     Sir, Mr Gan Kim Yong, in his motion, mentioned that Singaporeans are

Column: 210

cautiously optimistic about our future.  I would add that Singaporeans today worry a lot about our future.  The recession and the enduring structural unemployment have left a permanent dent on our collective psyche.  We have a better understanding of the realities of life.  No longer are we cocky about our future.  I still remember the days about 15 years ago when I interviewed fresh graduates from the university.  It was common then to meet young people who would expect their salary to double in three to four years' time.  And some of them were indeed getting it.  Today, the young people are more realistic.  With few jobs in the market, our young people are accepting short-term contracts of six months to two years.  No longer are they waiting for the iron rice bowl jobs. 

 

     Sir, what do Singaporeans worry about?  Let me relate some of these worries.

 

     Firstly, as individuals, we are concerned about our ability to adapt in a rapidly changing world.  We are worried about our jobs.  There is an acceptance amongst Singaporeans today that during one's working lifetime, one would be retrenched at least once.  Even for those of us with a reasonably secure job, we harbour a fear that somewhere along the line we will suffer a significant pay cut.  Interestingly, most Singaporeans do not blame the Government in this job market.  We understand that this is beyond what the Government could do.  Nonetheless, we are concerned that, as individuals, we would not be able to make much of a difference working alone.  So, in a way, we are hoping that the Government could step forward to galvanise us as a team to come up with counter-measures to tackle these challenges.

 

     Sir, we worry about our ability to maintain our current standard of living.  As we age, we are concerned about our ability to afford the rising health costs of

Column: 211

our loved ones.  We hear about the high cost of ineffective treatment, particularly of friends suffering from cancer, which drained the life-savings of individuals while making very little difference in their life expectancies.

 

     Secondly, Sir, there is a realisation of the vulnerability of Singapore as a nation in a highly competitive world.  As a nation, it seems that the era when we could make a good living just by being disciplined and working hard is coming to an end.  For many years now, Sir, we have seen our factories being relocated to low-cost countries.  In recent years, outsourcing has spread to technical and professional service jobs.  At the ground level, we see this trend continuing without abatement.  In the past, for those of us working in the multinational companies, we could pitch Singapore as a possible site for outsourcing.  Today, it is a non-starter to even mention Singapore in such discussions.  China and India are the preferred locations when MNCs take a pan Asia-Pacific view.  It seems that there is no effective counter measure.  Today, the destination for outsourcing that is Singapore has itself become the outsourcer, when we read about SIA and HP Singapore outsourcing their professional jobs to Malaysia and India.  Even as the economy generates more jobs, these new jobs are likely to be in the service sector, with lower salaries and poorer career prospects, as the data from MOM have demonstrated.  Furthermore, unless Singaporeans change our attitude towards service jobs, these jobs would continue to go to foreign workers.  We worry a lot about our future, and we also worry for our children's future, because job prospects are not as good as we have experienced when this trend of outsourcing accelerates.

 

     Sir, these two summarise the major concerns of Singaporeans.  For those of us looking forward to some answers in the President's Address, we were slightly

Column: 212

disappointed.  Perhaps the Prime Minister would find other occasions to address these concerns.  Just in case I present Singaporeans as worrywarts lost in bewilderment, there is actually one attribute about Singaporeans that will stand us in good stead. 

 

     Singaporeans have great confidence in our nation as a whole to overcome our challenges.  One might say it is contradictory, that we worry for ourselves, we worry about the vulnerability of Singapore, yet, as a group, we believe we could overcome the challenges.  The reason is that we have a very high respect for our political leaders.  Singaporeans trust the political system.  We trust that our Prime Minister would be able to lead us to a better tomorrow.  True, it is hard to visualise Singapore being a land of opportunity at this moment.  Nonetheless, we believe that the Government would be able to lay out the strategies to take us there.  This faith in our leaders is a strength which Prime Minister Lee will find invaluable in forging the nation forward to become a strong, resilient and yet, at the same time, compassionate society.

 

     Mr Speaker, Sir, one major issue we need to resolve in our mind as a people is this:  do we want more Government involvement or less Government involvement in our life?  Why do I say so?  In many speeches both inside and outside of this House, one could discern a viewpoint in Parliament that our people should become more self reliant.  We hear that the Government does not have a monopoly on all the ideas and wisdom, that we should move away from being a nation of employees towards being a nation of employers.  It seems that there is a school of thought in Cabinet that the Government should withdraw from the pervasive involvement in the past.  In the President's Address, the Government did not make it clear which direction it would be going.  To me, this is probably the one

Column: 213

factor that will set the tone of Prime Minister Lee's Government.  In answering the question, let us revisit the fundamentals. 

 

     I thank Dr Loo for presenting the analysis comparing Singapore versus the other nations.  But Singapore is an island state without natural resources.  If we compare ourselves with Finland and Denmark, one will know the big difference is that they have land and we have very little land.  Nationhood was, in fact, thrust upon us.  We have only about 40 years' history.  As far as resources are concerned, ours is the ultimate Malthusian society.  For those who have studied what is a Malthusian society will know that, in such a society, we would be dealing with declining marginal returns.  And being burdened with declining marginal returns would have been the natural order of things for Singapore.  It was the pro-active Government of MM Lee Kuan Yew that changed our fate.  Unlike better endowed countries, as mentioned earlier, a pro-active government is a prerequisite for Singapore.  It is not a choice.

 

     So, the real question is not whether the Government should be pro-active, but how pro-active it should be.  To me, Sir, one size does not fit all in answering this question.  In different spheres of our endeavours, the involvement of the Government should vary.  I believe that, in the case of direct economic participation, we could do with less government.  We should liberalise as much as possible and get out of the way for people to find niches to make a living.  For instance, in the past, we forbade restaurants from overflowing into the sidewalks.

Today, more and more outdoor refreshment outlets are approved.  Liberalising bar-top dancing is another

Column: 214

good example.  Unfortunately, the saga of the bars and KTVs in Joo Chiat is interesting and seems to present a two-mind view in these matters.  It seems that while, at the same time, we would like to create more space, we are unable to tolerate more chaotic environment.  Sir, in a sterile environment, as we all know, no new life form could take a foothold. Therefore, in the episode of Joo Chiat night life scene, what budding entrepreneurs would learn is that success does not depend on your ability to create value-add.  It depends a lot on the press, whether the press wants to highlight the negative aspects of things.  It depends a lot on who your Member of Parliament is.  In this case, Mr Chan Soo Sen is the Member of Parliament for Joo Chiat.

 

    Sir, in creating the environment for entrepreneurship, we should review the total ecosystem to ensure that it is possible for small businesses to form and to prosper. We should make sure that there is space left for them.  If every niche is already occupied and dominated by an existing entity, it would be very difficult for new enterprises to survive.  Sir, as such, I would urge the Government-linked companies to continue to withdraw from crowding out domestic entrepreneurs where possible.

 

    To ensure that this takes place, Sir, we have to go beyond applying the 'yellow page' rule as advocated by Mr Raymond Lim.  I see the involvement of Government in business as a natural outcome of our revenue surpluses in excess of expenditure accumulated in the Ministry of Finance as well as the various statutory boards.  Once surpluses are accumulated, investment of such surpluses would be a natural order of things.  And once we invest, the Government will get involved in business and therefore crowding out the private sector.  Today, such surpluses are invested with Temasek Holdings, the corporatised investment arm of the Ministry of Finance.  Sir, in the past, most

Column: 215

of these monies were reinvested in Singapore.  Yes, it increases Government's involvement in domestic economy and making it harder for the private sector to compete.  On the other hand, the liquidity is in the system.  Now, under the new Charter, Temasek is also sprouting wings overseas.  While reducing competition in Singapore, it is also diverting the liquidity out of Singapore.  Of course, this is not a problem at the moment as the banking system is flushed with cash.  In future, Sir, this might lead to a shortage of liquidity in Singapore.  And a shortage of liquidity would make it harder for young struggling enterprises to survive and prosper. 

 

     Furthermore, what is more important is the lack of job creation opportunity of this investment.  My point is whether it is better to leave the liquidity in the private sector and thereby allowing private initiative to find a better use of the money than have it taxed and vested in the public sector, corporatised or otherwise.  As it is, to me, Sir, the best jobs today in the corporate world are not found in the private sector, ie, not in the private companies. They are in the Government-linked companies (GLCs).  This is not necessarily the best environment to develop a more entrepreneurial ecosystem as the risk factor for the individual involved is rather low. To prevent the balance from being tilted even more towards Temasek, I think there is a need to ensure that Government does not intentionally set up generating surpluses in our annual budget as well as for the statutory boards as their objective or one of their objectives.  In my view, the best approach is to tax our economy just sufficiently to cover the needs of the Government, and no more. The various statutory boards should also not be allowed to keep the large cash hoards beyond their needs. Otherwise, they would be inclined to build monumental buildings for themselves.  Where the trend of generating surpluses is evident, I would

Column: 216

urge the Government to cut taxes and usage charges where possible.

 

    Sir, while Singaporeans would like to see less Government involvement in running business in the economy, we would like to see more Government involvement in other domains where only Government can participate.  Here, I am referring to infrastructure development, healthcare and education.  We should learn the painful lesson in our attempt to corporatise, for instance, PSA.  By changing the performance measures of PSA, we allowed PSA to lose focus on putting Singapore's interest first.  Similarly, as we corporatised the utilities sector, we should learn the lesson of massive power outage we experienced recently.  We should accept that there are certain prerequisite roles for the Government.  And in some of these roles, we should not measure their performance by commercial terms, by the rate of return of investment.  Healthcare is one of these areas.

 

    Sir, Mr Gan mentioned that Singapore is at a crossroad.  How we proceed from here will depend to a great extent the choices we make today.  It is paramount that the Prime Minister seizes the moment and leads the nation with wisdom and boldness, to break with past practices, if necessary.  So far, the signs are tantalisingly positive.  I see the initiative on the integrated entertainment centre with casino as the centrepiece.  I see the relaxation of entry requirements for students and visitors from China and other developing countries, as we emphasise tourism and education, as some of the key areas.  We knew that taking such steps would bring some measures of chaos and disorderliness into our society.  However, we should re-examine our institutional instincts and not be bound by moribund mindset. We should aim high so as to realise the vision for Singapore:  the land of opportunity.  By setting the seven priorities as laid out

Column:217

in the President's Address, I believe the stage is set for Singapore to realise our full potential.

   

     Mr Alexander Chan Meng Wah (Nominated Member): Mr Speaker, Sir, the President, in his Address, has painted a broad vision for Singaporeans.  While this vision is not entirely new or surprising to many, for me, it provided the comfort of familiarity and a refreshed viewpoint, both in its areas of emphases, as well as in its subtleties.

 

     It has positioned our view ahead and, more importantly, our approach going forward more clearly.  His address was less about "what" and "where", but more about "how".  In particular, the words, "making Singapore a land of opportunity for our people, so that this will long be the place where talent, energy and vitality congregate" should strike a very strong chord for the business community and its economic players, as well as for the ordinary citizen.  I want to dwell a little bit on the concept of opportunity.

 

    Opportunity has first got to be created and recognised, in our hearts and minds, and then to be taken.  In recent debates in this House on the subject of entrepreneurship, Members have passionately talked about the need for re-building this spirit.  Our forefathers and mothers, as immigrants, came with a healthy dose of adventure, courage, enterprise, and, very likely, of fear and uncertainty as well.  They did not know what lay beyond the horizon, save perhaps for the hope of finding a better place.  The opportunity, though unknown, was imagined and created in their hearts and minds. 

 

    In the course of the recent past few generations of Singaporeans, we have modernised our country, added to our stock of knowledge, become facile with

Column: 218

high technology and complex systems, built an international city state, and in the process, won quite a few accolades in many fields of our chosen endeavours.  Life has become more orderly on the surface and we depend upon working systems for maximum productivity and stability.  We could do it because our early generation leaders had the vision, our people had the guts and were willing to go along, and equally notably, we could find economic partners to show us the way and to work with us through what was often at that time uncharted territory.  The history of the Jurong Industrial Estate rising from our swamps and the subsequent growth of manufacturing in Singapore is a key testimony of this wonderful tripartite combination.  Again, the opportunity was imagined and created in our minds, and then we acted on it as if by faith.

 

     We are familiar with the electronics growth in our manufacturing industry, those economic partners in those pioneering days were primarily American, European, and some Japanese.  Those companies were themselves growing enterprises, looking everywhere for more markets and for more resources.  Most of those companies forged abroad without formal economic support from their own governments.  In fact, we farsightedly found it expedient to provide some of them the financial and fiscal incentives.  Some of these companies, such as HP, GE, Motorola, Philips, Matsushita, still exist today, probably several tens or hundreds of times bigger in size than before, and they created for Singapore hundreds of thousands of man-years of work.

 

     They came to Singapore and the Far East as manufacturers of goods, later as product developers and marketers.   This led to the emergence and development of our current generation of local manufacturing companies, often under-value-labelled locally as the supporting

Column:219

industries.  Today, slightly better terminology labels them as part of the value chain or even more accurately as part of an ecosystem, with each part providing its own essential value.

 

    It is instructive to note that those SMEs that formed the supporting industries then were started by entrepreneurs who probably knew very little about how to do what they perceived to be the requirements of those MNCs.  So how did they succeed?

 

    Bob Reiss, a successful entrepreneur and author of the book, "Low-Risk, High-Reward: Starting and Growing your Small Business with Minimal Risk", says: "Entrepreneurship is the recognition and pursuit of opportunity without regard to the resources you currently control, with confidence that you can succeed, with the flexibility to change course as necessary, and with the will to rebound from setbacks."  Those early SMEs saw a glimmer of opportunity, imagined they could achieve success, and they acted.

 

    Our forefathers, when they braved the high seas on the least safe of vessels, and the founders of those SMEs, certainly qualify to use the entrepreneur label.  Many of these first generation SMEs today are themselves regional companies and a few even global MNCs in their own right.  Some of them still have their founders at the helm. 

 

    An ecosystem is not organised just by economic transactions.  Like all natural ecosystems, it thrives or not depending upon the interaction among all its participants in its environment, there is a more-or-less survival-of-the-fittest reckoning system, a continuous rebalancing that happens, and catastrophic consequences often happen when the status quo suffers a disruptive change. 

 

     Recognising this fine balance of any ecosystem, we need to preserve its

Column: 220

chemistry.  This is not to be interpreted to mean the same thing as an iron rice bowl, or that we do not touch the status quo.  It is to mean that employers, Government policy-makers and stakeholders have the responsibility to try their best to create jobs and grow the web of relationships, not to destroy them.  I do not think we can today repeat a forced systematic driving out of whole legitimate businesses or industries, however low value-adding they may be, just because they did not fit a masterplan.  Mr Inderjit Singh mentioned yesterday about the NIH (or not invented here) syndrome used to deal with project proposals.  I agree with him that there is a good dose of this in many places in our administration, and this may stem in part from internal competition for recognition, or from our misplaced notion of scarcity of resources.  If we were less dogmatic about our policies, who knows, we may have spawned a local IKEA from one of our local innovative wood furniture makers in Singapore.


    Our economy has grown in both breadth and depth.  The first generation of MNC partners have come in the 1970s and 80s, and most have either expanded into the Asian region or even left Singapore, to where costs are lower and markets are bigger.  The stakes are significantly higher now, for individual firms as well as for countries, for each investment decision taken or not taken, and each move made or not made can be a fairly defining and decisive one.

 

     Sir, I think most Singaporeans feel that we do not lack leaders who have a proper grasp of a vision for our country.  I also think the majority of our adult citizens would say with conviction that they are willing to work hard and to go the extra mile if necessary.  So we must turn our attention to the question of who our future partners for development and success should be.  The President has thrown some light onto this question.  He called for us to work with our ASEAN

Column: 221

neighbours for a common good, and at the same time, to cultivate our ties with China and India.  With rising competition from gigantic regional countries, no more important the concept of a thriving cooperative ASEAN economic trade area than now. 

 

     Our new economic partners of tomorrow would be more Asian than Western in nature.  There would be new differences that could arise from this.  In my view, the past MNCs from the US and Europe were leading corporations of their day with leadership practices in their areas of expertise.  These may have been in manufacturing processes, quality systems, project management, legal contracting, IT, whatever.  The new partners of tomorrow may not be that in advance of our own practices because the economic space is now more crowded; they may not have the resources like before because of extreme competition; or they may not even be as willing a partner. 

This means that Singaporeans have to be able to create their own value in their ecosystems.  In other words, we have to bring value and innovation to the table, and we have to be able to create opportunities and solve problems ourselves, or as a part of larger teams.

 

     These are newer skills and this poses new challenges for a large part of our working population, as well as for many of our business leaders, as they are more used to the leading role played by our first generation multinational partners in industrialisation.  In the next lap, Singapore firms will have to come to the fore and take the lead, and only then reap the benefits as our western MNC economic partners did before.  This leadership will demand responsibilities beyond pure economics as there should be the concomitant corporate social responsibility as well.

 

Column: 222

     A flexible and pro-business approach has also been re-emphasised by the President.  Given today's high stakes game of winning business and investments, and accelerated by the global high technology world, I urge that every Government official, every decision-maker, and every regulatory department, act with extreme urgency and speed.  One of the members of the international panel on university education was quoted in our media as saying, and I paraphrase, that "it does not matter whether a country is big or small, but rather, whether you are slow or fast".  Can our Government departments make speedy decisions, even as they may not know whether the decisions made are right or wrong?  Well, if it cannot be deliberately pro-business, perhaps it can be immediately flexible.  So, I offer a twist to PM Lee's duck and hippo tale:  if our bureaucrats cannot duck the proposal, at least be prepared to cheer "hip hip hurray"!

 

     I have sometimes heard our civil service claim that most problems and issues we face in Singapore have been studied, and studied extensively and deeply as well. Indeed, we are all thankful for this rigour, and I would rather have that than no analysis and careful thought into our policies.  However, every well-conceived analysis has to have a model or paradigm of decision-making attached to it.  Just like the cold war methods of intelligence analysis spawned decisions pertinent to that era, they could not be effective against current-day 9/11 style terrorism. 

 

     The world has changed, not just in the political sphere, but also in the economic, business and social senses.  If we admit that, then we must also admit that not every policy issue studied and implemented may necessarily produce the desired outcome for Singapore.  This just means Government has to continually

Column: 223

adjust its methods, processes and, most importantly, our paradigms for Singapore.  Personally, I actually see this happening already.  This, too, our President has mentioned in his speech, when he said, "we will encourage more people to dream of new ideas, pursue them with passion, and open up new opportunities for our economy".  These new dreams require different interpretations for sure, or our dreamers remain that, or they spawn a new psychiatric industry, or they take their dreams elsewhere.  So I am glad to hear anecdotes that our civil servants are at least asking "why not".  But do not stop there and then sabotage the idea behind the walls.

 

     Sir, I would like to bring up several questions for all Singaporeans to ponder.  Firstly, do we possess the ability to imagine or create opportunities in our hearts and minds in the first place?  It appears from the constant drone of feedback that this is perhaps our fundamental problem to begin with.  Do we lack the education our forefathers and earlier entrepreneurs wished they had the opportunity to have?  Our Education Ministry has tons of metrics to show how well our students and schools do.  Do we also lack the opportunity to be exposed to the global community in this Internet and international media age?   So if well-educated people, electronically connected to the rest of the world, cannot see the opportunities, something has not gone that right.

 

     This then brings me to our future generation and our youth.  The future world will pose many more questions and fewer definitive answers.  Firms today are often unable to predict their own business levels beyond three to six months ahead.  We will be less able to predict which technologies and business models will win in the market places of the future.  That being the case, how must we approach our planning for manpower,  skills and competencies?  Our children must be

Column: 224

prepared for many changes in their working lifetime, be able to cope with continuous learning as required, and operate in a multi-cultural environment.  This in turn means that they have to be offered as many choices of study and learning as possible, and to be given as varied a school experience as we can give.  I already see this beginning to happen.

 

     We must give our children a new context for survival and belonging.  Their world is no longer one of "we are good, so we can get the business".  Students of science and technology must also understand ancient history, culture and people.  If our appreciation of the arts is limited only to that of Western high art form, they will not appreciate the art of the common folk in this region.  So while I support the birth of the special schools for the arts, sports, special needs, etc, let us also ensure that our future generation is firmly plugged into our neighbourhood, so to speak.  The renewed emphasis on sports participation in schools, rather than sports only to win medals to be put onto the school principal's report card, is another example of going in the right direction.  To make Singapore our home, this home must be one full of life's experiences.  Study alone cannot fulfil this task, but a broad-based holistic education can.

 

     On the area of metrics, measures and KPIs, may I say that we already do too much benchmarking.  Having measures and KPIs for everything does not necessarily result in better outcomes.  It reminds me of an Olympic Games video which depicted some Olympic heroes and athletes in action. The caption read: "Speed is measured in seconds. Distance in metres. But we can't measure courage."  I also recall what Mr Hsieh Fu Hua, the CEO of SGX, said among friends when he commented on what he got from school.  He said that what made him, and what he took away, were more the

Column: 225

intangibles than the tangibles.  I concur with him, since it is by chance, that we shared the same teachers.  At that time, even the tangibles were not measured.  US psychologist B F Skinner said it more succinctly: "Education is what survives when what has been learnt has been forgotten."

 

     In closing, quite a few of our Members have spoken about the tsunami.  I did not have the opportunity to experience the aftermath first-hand and so I cannot relate the personal tales as others have.  Nevertheless, I have learned a few lessons which I now wish to share.

 

    One, the survival of any community or country depends upon the mettle of the little people, the common people.  This will ring true as we see happening in the reconstruction.  Observers will be able to see for themselves if there is differential progress made by the various countries hit by the recent tsunamis, depending upon each community's spirit.  Our youth today get passed from primary to secondary to tertiary schools, each one optimising their own organisation goals.  For our males, the SAF takes over and they then pass them on to the real world.  We lack the continuous community and organisational vehicles to transport them across all these organisational boundaries today.  How then can we expect them to sink roots and to have them grow long and deep, so that when the floodwaters recede a new plant grows?

 

     Two, we cannot ignore the gentle or weak signals, as they may portend a disaster yet to come.  The reports of the tsunami, the lack of warning, the lack of sharing these warning signs, the lack of proper reporting, then lack of faith in the warnings, all show our custom to the status quo and our continued belief in the paradigms that brought us success in the past.  More light-heartedly, I am not

Column: 226

saying that a spouse's constant nagging is a gentle signal, but when that nagging stops, often a tsunami follows.

 

    Three, the tsunami shows also that knowledge is important to understand our complex world. The story of the 10-year old British girl who learnt her geography lessons well and remembered the tell-tale signs of an oncoming tsunami, and warned the people around her, is especially convincing.  Today, this generation has been more or less fully educated about tsunamis, and it will be remembered because there was a context.  We must really check what is learnt, not what is taught.  Let us find new contexts for learning.

 

     Four, the little girl's knowledge only had value because people listened to her. Would a Singaporean parent or adult have given the same credence to our 10 year-old?  Talk about listening to the young!  Yes, there is a big difference between listening and heeding.  Action is only taken after we heed, not when we just listen.

 

     Finally, while there is an apparent calm after this tsunami, there is still a real and present danger.  Some of our statistics may show improvement in our country situation, but the underlying threat of future economic tsunamis still exists for us, and many of our citizens are still suffering various forms of hardship.  Our reconstruction must continue.

 

     Yesterday, this House heard a question on how to get our older citizens to engage in a more active lifestyle.  My answer would be: by getting them to get into the habit when they were in school.  Our changes must start with our young.  Sir, I am very much in agreement with engaging and energising our young.

 

     Our President did not just paint a picture of paradise, as was pointed out by one Member yesterday.  To me, he

Column: 227

painted a picture of the continuing work that needs to be done by all of us.  It is a picture of opportunity, perhaps on a canvas unseen, but it is certainly for us to seize.

 

     I support the motion.

 

     The Minister of State for Trade and Industry (Mr Heng Chee How): Mr Speaker, Sir, thank you for allowing me to join in the debate.  We want Singapore to be a land of opportunity and, for today, I would focus my comments on one area of this great endeavour, namely, the area of community development.

 

     I have a habit of analysing things in terms of supply and demand.  In general, many of the actions of Government Ministries in the Addenda that they released would help promote new investments, anchor existing ones, lower barriers to activity and participation of various kinds and strengthen defence against predictable threats.  In doing so, they help increase the likelihood and supply of opportunities.

 

     Achievement comes from Singaporeans taking full advantage of the growing supply of opportunities.  In other words, fostering a strong demand for opportunities is equally important. 

 

     I think there is an innate ability among people to see opportunity, especially when the word gets around.  There would be the more well-informed, the ambitious and the entrepreneurial who would be quick to seize the first-mover advantage.  Then there would be the broad body of the population who would also get in the act when they sense the benefits and are clearer about how to extract those gains.  They would form that demand for opportunity.

 

     I asked myself whether there are conditions in the overall social environment that would help maximise

Column: 228

this demand.  And, if so, what could we do to nurture these conditions?  I think there are two such conditions.  There could be more, but I would speak on the two.  One affects stability, and the other, robustness.

 

     An unstable society risks breaking apart and a divided society would not be an attractive place to live, work, play or to bring up the next generation. 

 

     What are the key risks to our stability?  First, when some groups feel left behind despite their best efforts, especially economically.  Next, when some groups are influenced ideologically to do irrational things.

 

     I wish to confine my comments today to the first type.  When we listen to the heartbeat of our economy, we know that the less-skilled and the older workers face particular threat of displacement.  There is also a certain correlation between the two groups.  When we look at our demographic trends, we see a rapidly ageing population.  What this means is that more such individuals and their families may face difficulties unless more could be done to help them move over to higher ground faster.

 

     In the aftermath of the tsunami disaster, the saying "Time and tide wait for no man" has taken on a whole new sense of urgency.  That disaster showed that those who escaped had the initiative to run for their lives, while those who perished were caught unaware, or had stood transfixed by the change, or who could not get out in time.  These are also important lessons for all who have to deal and live with the great forces of economic and technological restructuring.  In this connection, even as the Government and the NTUC continue with many efforts to help workers prolong their working lives and improve their employability, I think more must be done.

 

Column: 229

     The Community Development Councils already run schemes that help families in financial straits and those seeking employment.  They also work with and support initiatives of the grassroots organisations and voluntary welfare organisations in addressing the needs of the poor in the local communities.

 

     In helping, we should continue to concentrate on a family-focus, family-centric and 3P approach - the 3Ps being public, private and people sectors.  From experience, many of these persons needing help have a whole host of issues and problems.  Becoming unemployed is one of the problems.  They are often also in serious arrears with their rents, utilities, conservancy and other necessary payments.  Their financial situation affects the mood at home, demoralises the children in their studies, and so on.  Efforts to help them from any one angle, such as job placement, is often undermined by urgent and entrenched problems in the other areas.  A family-centric focus gives the best chance of assessing the real attitude of the help-seeker, his will to improve and the best chance of stabilising the environment as that family works at improving their lot.

 

     The expertise needed to counsel, tutor and correct, does not lie solely within the public sector organisations.  This is recognised.  Hence, there is ongoing tie-up between the CDCs, grassroots bodies and VWOs for counselling follow-up.  CDCs also check with employers, in some cases, whether such workers are staying on in their newly-acquired jobs.  In many cases, the link is sequential, meaning that the person is referred after he is helped financially or with job placement.  And, even when it is concurrent, it may not be as integrated as it could be.

 

    This partnership approach could be further strengthened to rally around the

Column: 230

family, forming a ring of encouragement within which that family would make the effort.  Such an approach is by nature resource-intensive, as with all forms of intensive care.  This also requires much closer coordination between partners, so that they mutually reinforce.

 

This will also help counter sob-story-assistance-shopping behaviour by some.    The more we can synergise these efforts and improve coordination between Government, grassroots and VWO networks, the more we will be able to customise and target help properly, thus alleviating suffering in the present generation and fostering real recovery and hope for the future.

 

     This way of community care is dynamic and goes beyond mere assessment of eligibility for ad hoc financial hand-outs and pain-relief.

 

     I see a particular opportunity at this point in time.  The overall economy is improving.  Unemployment has dropped from closer to 5% to 3.4%, with fair prospects of coming down further.  What is happening is that those who have been cyclically unemployed, ie, who got the sack because of poor business and not poor skills, are progressively finding jobs as the economy picks up and demand returns.

 

     This means that we can focus more attention on those less employable but who want to help themselves, as the total number of unemployed moderates. This focus and intensive care is also essential, because the gaps and problems that we have to help this group of workers overcome are much more than those for the average cyclically unemployed.

 

     With a more buoyant economy, I believe the Government is also in a better financial position to consider more help for such groups.

 

     In an age of turbulence, such action will be increasingly crucial in leaving no

Column: 231

one behind in this generation and the next, and in keeping the social fabric strong and intact.  This movement from "Relief to Recovery to Rebuilding" will require more and ongoing investment, coordination and much leg work, and I urge that more resources be so directed.

 

     I move on to the second enabling condition, that which enhances robustness in society.  To me, that enabler is an active citizenry.

 

     A vibrant society and a land of opportunity and opportunity-seizing require more than stability.  There must be robustness and vigour, alertness and agility, a spirit of enterprise, adaptability and a maturity in thought and behaviour.  This comes about only when the people and groups in society make it happen.  The more we can foster this process, the better it will be for us, because our society will gain more "bounce".

 

     Ongoing development and recent events make me feel that Singaporeans and companies in Singapore are now more ready to become such active citizens and active corporate citizens.

 

     The tremendous response from Singaporeans and organisations in helping those hit by the recent earthquake and tsunami is a good illustration.  The donations were generous but, more importantly, the spontaneity was outstanding.  Individuals and groups, formal and informal, took the initiative and volunteered, organised, mobilised and rallied for a common worthy cause.

 

     The tremendous response of Singaporeans in turning out to support the team at the finals of the Tiger Cup is another example of social solidarity and suppport.

 

     But beyond these big and visible events, there are many Singaporeans who

Column: 232

have contributed their time, money, effort and expertise to causes and passions that they believe in.  In the process, they have made this country a better place for all.

 

     Singaporeans have seen what they are capable of, individually and in partnership, when they want to.  What is important is that we do not let these opportunities become just a blip on the radar screen.  We must build on the momentum and try to achieve sustained impact and improvement, lock in the gains and move society up a notch.

 

    The opportunities are without limit.  There are so many needs and possibilities in our community, short term and long term, that an energised citizenry (both individual and corporate) can address.

 

     In this area too, we cannot simply assume that intention will result in achievement.  To turn this opportunity into strength and advantage, we must now step up our efforts and investments to spur active citizenship and the closely-related area of volunteerism.

 

     For example, better coordination between those who identify needs and those who manage volunteer networks will reduce attrition and improve outcomes.  More focus on working with the school system to unleash the true potential of the Community Involvement Programme for students and teachers.  Improving the skills of volunteer managers so that they effectively develop, empower and entrust volunteers with challenging missions that will lead to greater satisfaction and motivation.  Helping volunteers form groups to exchange ideas, discuss problems and encourage one another will keep the fires burning.  For companies, more recognition of their contributions to society will improve their reputation, and help them stay on as good corporate citizens.  Hopefully, other companies will also emulate them.

 

Column: 233

     These ideas are not new or glamorous, but fundamentals are like that.  And when these fundamentals are taken seriously, they will yield good returns to society.  In the light of developments and events that have taken place, now is the best time to put our foot to the accelerator and unleash the potential in our people.  As we do so, our society will become more dynamic, resilient, passionate and compassionate.  And it will be a society that is both willing and able to cheer and support its members as they boldly pursue their dreams in a land of opportunity.

 

     Sir, I support the motion.

 

    

     Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong (Non-Constituency Member): Thank you, Mr Speaker, Sir, for allowing me to participate in this debate.  I support the President and the six broad outlines that he had addressed in his opening speech. In particular, I see more of the Government's policy focus on caring for the people  -  more than economic profitability this time round.

 

     But before I begin, I would like to take this opportunity to praise the efforts of the Government, the SAF, the doctors, nurses and relief workers, the volunteers and the many people of Singapore for coming together at a time of great international humanitarian crisis, to pour their heart and soul out, to contribute, to volunteer their time, effort and money to help our fellow humans caught in this great tsunami disaster.

Column: 234

fellow Singaporean.  Well done.  To the Government of these people, I also want to say, please trust our people and have more confidence that we will rise up as a united nation in any crisis.  The people of Singapore will be willing to set aside their personal concerns, differences and agendas, to be led by the Government for national unity and for the common good of society.
