Just take a look at our parliamentary colleague, Mr Chiam See Tong.  Without fanfare and any public announcement, he stood with fellow Singaporeans for the tsunami victims and went around his Potong Pasir constituency to collect and quietly raised $33,000 for the Red Cross Tidal Wave Fund.  You see, when required, non-government party politicians are always prepared to stand together with the people and the Government for the greater good of society and for national unity.  We may not agree politically but we are all pro-Singapore, pro-society and pro-humanity.

 

     Next, I will touch on the fifth and sixth points raised by the President.  The President wants to encourage Singaporeans to balance work life and fulfilment in personal goals and family life.  This is good in theory, and probably applicable to only those top 25%-30% of Singaporeans who are very established and successful in their career or businesses.  But for the majority of the heartlanders, theirs is a lifestyle from two hands to a few mouths, with little spare cash to spare for luxuries and wants.

 

     The last 10 years have been very difficult years for many Singaporeans.  First, many people followed the past Government's advice to invest their money and CPF savings in the stock market and lost badly.  Then the people followed the Government's drive for asset ownership, and now many people are

Column: 235

caught in negative equity. They cannot sell their flats or property without still owing the bank money.  Then the Asian financial crisis came and outsourcing became the norm, and many people lost their jobs.  Those above 40 found great difficulties getting back to the workforce, with little job fulfilment and prospect, if they managed to get one.  Theirs is where the stress is highest because there are many demands for their limited income   -  from housing, PUB, transport, children, parents, aged parents, etc.  There are many mouths to feed with the limited income.

 

     Now, especially with the Government intending to draw in more talent from all around the world, they are even more worried about their job security and promotion prospect.  They ask: why is the Government allowing more foreigners in to compete with them for their livelihood and promotion?  Yes, as a nation, we need more talents and foreigners to augment our population, but we must also be careful not to over supply the labour force with cheaper workers at the expense of our citizens' livelihood.  The Government needs to draw a thin balance in this matter between the needs of businesses and the cost of living for individual Singaporeans.

 

     When I went on a house-to-house visit in Choa Chu Kang, and I asked the residents and shopkeepers there, "How's life?" or "How's business?", a common theme in their reply is this, "Just surviving"  -  koay jit, koay jit, ciak buay pah, yao buay si, meaning can pass the days, won't die of hunger but eating is not fulfilling.  I, and I think many Singaporeans, sincerely hope that the Government can and will lower the burden of Singaporeans living in Singapore further.

 

     Sir, to encourage a more balanced and fulfilling family life, the Government could help by reducing entrance fees to our

Column: 236

world-class and world-renowned facilities like the Bird Park, the Zoo, Night Safari and Underwater World, just to name a few.  We have very beautiful parks and very well-managed facilities.  But for a family outing of six  -  two parents, two children, maybe with a grandparent and the maid  -  to one of these attractions, it can easily cost more than $100 per outing per family per weekend on one sunny Sunday.  How many Singaporean families can afford such luxuries?

 

     To genuinely support family life and change Singaporeans' mentality that "there is nothing to see and nothing to do in Singapore", the Government should consider scrapping the entrance fees for Singaporeans bringing their families to these parks and facilities.  Then, when it is free or at very low cost, more Singaporeans will take the effort to visit and spend time at these world-class facilities, rather than to take the effort to drive over to Malaysia for the long weekend.

 

     On the last point raised by the President on engaging and inspiring a new generation of Singaporeans to commit and be active citizens, I would like to ask the Government what concrete steps it is taking to open up the Singapore civil society.  What is the best sign of improvement to show the opening up of our political system?

 

     I believe that it is high time for the Government to support and promote the growth  of more civil societies and independent think tanks not closely aligned with the Government.  Without outright cash funding, the Government can help out by allowing the free or low cost use of excess office space for these civil societies.  With the promotion of a vibrant civil society, it is another sign of the coming of age of our society.

 

     Next, the new Government under the leadership of our new Prime Minister

Column:237

should also take the opportunity to remove all the restrictions that our past Governments had imposed on the people.  Reinstate the 

rights of our citizens to freedom of speech, freedom of movement and assembly, as stated in our Constitution, and in particular, the right to public demonstration.  Our people must be free to assemble and show their unhappiness or happiness over policies through peaceful and public means, as provided for in our Constitution.

 

     How to build an active and concerned citizenry?  The political apathy of our young is not innate, but because of a lack of choice - a lack of genuine choice.  The lack of prospects for anything alternative to the governing party is turning young people off from politics and civil society.  The lack of trust and faith in a fair electoral system and the hope that they could make genuine changes in the political arena are making them politically disinterested.

 

     Just take a look at the Tiger Cup soccer game last Sunday.  55,000 Singaporeans turned up in red to support the Lions.  Why?  Is it not because they believe that their presence to support the Lions will make a difference in the Lions' winning or losing the game?  There is hope and there is prospect for change in a fair game.  Similarly, if our citizens and young know that their choice and decision do make an impact on society, they will make the extra effort to take on active citizenship.

 

     Now, what is the best sign that the game is being played fairly?  Show it in a free and fair election system.  The political system and the General Elections must not only be free and fair.  More importantly, as I have said previously, it must be seen by one and all - local and international communities - as free and fair.  And what better way to silence all

Column: 238

the critics, myself included, than the setting up of an Independent Elections Commission, headed maybe by a retired judge or comprising people of public repute like retired CEOs, people of public standing, ex-NMPs, Government and non-Government MPs, appointed to this independent commission.

 

     If the Government is good, there is no need for it to be afraid of appointing or setting up an Independent Elections Commission to help conduct and promote our image of a free and fair election system, and face the competition from us - the weak and maybe a bit disorganised Opposition, as it is.  This lack of a fair political system is the greatest disgruntlement any Singaporeans have against the past Governments.  If the Government plays the electoral game fairly, and removes itself as the referee while playing in the game itself,  it will silence both local and international critics immediately about any unfair electioneering activities.

 

     Finally, as our Government helps to promote democracy in countries like Iraq, with the sending of our troops there to help in the election, or even in Myanmar to push for democracy there, it should also help to speed up our own democratic evolvement so that citizens of Singapore can truly live in our own democratic society.

 

     With this, I thank you, Sir, for your indulgence.

 

     Mr Wee Siew Kim (Ang Mo Kio): Mr Speaker, Sir, I support the Motion of Thanks to the President.

 

     We began this year with a heavy heart.  Nonetheless, a sense of hope and optimism is palpable.  Singaporeans have rallied around the plight of the victims of the tsunami tragedy, contributing generously and spontaneously.  In Singapore, we enjoy an oasis of calm and

Column: 239

security.  In response to such tragedies, Singaporeans' universal demonstration of love, empathy and support is indeed heartwarming.  And to our NCMP, Mr Steve Chia, I would say that this is the only demonstration that we want to see, not massive demonstration on our streets, as he has just advocated, that we should allow.  In response also to such tragedy, we see that the human spirit is indeed enduring and resilient.  To the hon. Member, Mr Chiam, this is what I call an example of true resilience, not so much that there are still two Opposition Members in the Chamber.

 

The people over by the window

 

     During the run-up to Christmas, the atmosphere in Orchard Road was perceptibly celebratory.  It was a time to shop and be merry!  And so amidst the "ka-ching" of the cash registers, Singaporeans, regardless of race and religion, had celebrated the year-end season.  With the forecasted economic growth of between 3% and 5%, we have reasons to be optimistic.  But are all boats lifted by the rising tide?  In spite of our economic recovery, there are groups of people who do not, and who cannot, join in the celebrations.  They have not benefited from our economic growth and progress and they need a helping hand.

 

     They are the Singaporeans "over by the window".  I borrow this phrase "over by the window" from a book by Ms Kuroyanagi, a Japanese author and Asia's first UNICEF Goodwill Ambassador.  She is referring to people on the fringe; those left out in the cold.

 

     Surely, you may ask, are there such people existing in Singapore?  After all, we have an extensive welfare reach.  We do good work through our voluntary welfare organisations (VWOs), grassroots organisations (GROs) and through the many assistance schemes.  However, any social worker, any grassroots leader and

Column: 240

MP can tell you that Singaporeans "over by the window" are amongst us.

 

     More often than we would like, they fall beneath our radar.  Our social support fails to reach them.  Some are not aware that they can apply for help or are unable to do so, which is frequently the case with the elderly, the minors, the mentally or physically impaired.  Others refuse to request for help out of a sense of pride and independence but inevitably they cause unnecessary suffering to family members.

 

     In the course of my work, I came across a family whose three children have not eaten for three days.  There was also a baby whose birth was not registered because her young parents could not afford the $18.00 registration fee.  Or the poor retrenched man with three bright daughters but was unable to pass a reading test, which is the prerequisite for his bus driver interview, because he could not afford reading glasses.  He was told - come back when you have the glasses.

 

     These are our people "over by the window".  They can only stare into the party from the outside.  Other such people by the window that I would hazard to include are our elderly destitute, the mentally handicapped, the physically disabled, the long-term unemployed and under-employed, the neglected minors, the abused (both adults and minors), the "un-integrated" amongst us (these are people with difficulty fitting into the mainstream such as those with severe autism, Asperger's), or what we deem as outcasts amongst us (prisoners, ex-prisoners) and also the self-destructed (drug, alcohol and gambling addicts).  As you can see, they are all out in the cold.

 

An inclusive society - A review of the "Many Hands" approach

 

     The challenge for us is how to improve upon our current welfare delivery system

Column: 241

so that we can identify these people, minimise their numbers and reduce the time they need to pick themselves up.  As far as possible, we want to integrate them into our mainstream society.

 

     Singapore's approach towards the weak, the poor and the helpless is the "many hands" system, a partnership involving our VWOs, the Government, GROs, community groups, religious groups, families and individuals.  However, it is not an equal partnership and VWOs bear a substantial responsibility of managing and delivering welfare, with support from other groups.  Yet, our experience in the last few years has shown us that depending so heavily on VWOs to identify and assist needy Singaporeans may not be sufficient.  There is a limit to what these VWOs can do.  There are still gaps.  The Government can lend a hand to enhance the outreach.  Hence, MOS and Mayor Heng's concept of dynamic community care, which was just articulated, is extremely encouraging. It is an acknowledged mission that there is a place for everyone in Singapore, ensuring that the less able are not left behind.  I am much encouraged by two points that MCYS is paying attention to.  They are: enhancing systematic case management and building up a "silver" industry in Singapore.

 

     Here, I am paying particular attention to the elderly amongst us.  Unknown to many in Singapore, there are increasingly more elderly households in Singapore.  The number of wholly elderly households increased from 10,400 in 1990 to 25,700 in 2000 - a rate of 9.4% per year. And 12.3% of all residents over the age of 65 years are not living with a spouse or children.  Who are they and how many need customised attention?  This is why I am enthused when I hear that more help is on the way with an enhancement in systematic case management.  We should

Column: 242

devote resources to locate and map out such families.  Many families would not need any assistance.  But awareness by their local community - the RCs, the NCs and the CDCs - is probably good enough.  But then there are families that need particular attention.  This is where focused case management would be extremely helpful.

 

     Amongst the needs and requests that I come across from older residents, I find that the one that I am most hard put to address adequately is the request for jobs.  Much as we want to enable more Singaporeans to continue working into their 60s and stay active, many today are unable to find employment.  Hence, the mention of building up a "silver" industry signals a focus of attention to this segment. They need attention.  One can no longer brush off this problem as too small in absolute numbers to merit attention, or fob it off by saying that their children and family members ought to take primary responsibility, or avoid the problem altogether by the fear that a moral hazard is created, as too many fall upon Government for help if it is too readily available.  These older people who need jobs are generally beyond the age that most employers would consider seriously, generally less educated and less energetic.  Once displaced, many are unable to get back into the workforce easily.  A focused approach to tackling this problem is key to eventually dwindle down the numbers.  An elderly earning his or her own keeps would see his or her self-esteem rise.  For some, life may have dealt them a poor hand of cards.  But for those who are prepared to help themselves, and are physically able to do so, we must have ways and avenues to reach out and lend a hand.  Employer groups can be co-opted in.  One example is the elderly directing  traffic in multi-storey car parks in Japan.  These silver-haired wardens are invariably smartly dressed in uniforms with impeccably clean white gloves.  I am sure they carry out

Column: 243

their job with pride.  And I am also sure that an electronic sign may suffice in most cases and would displace them.  But there must be a good reason why there are still so many of these traffic directors around.

 

     I remember we used to have tax allowances for companies to automate, to raise productivity.  Maybe it is time now to consider some tax relief for employers to retain specific jobs for some of the needy, less educated, physically deteriorated, older workers amongst our populace.  Beyond what the Government can encourage employers to do, there are also other avenues that can be explored.  Take the example of the itinerant hawker licences.  Why do we not review the restrictions again with a view of further freeing up?  Or even the way we tender out hawker stalls.  Must it all be on a purely competitive and highest bid wins approach?  If one is allowed to open a hawker stall with only elderly workers, I am sure it would find an appreciative and loyal following.  I am sure the elderly amongst us can do a lot more than just clean the tables and clear the dishes.  Or even

relook the ways school and factory canteens are managed.  Here, I am totally sympathetic with Mayor Amy Khor's point which she made yesterday that her mother brought her up with the income from a school canteen stall.  Many of us have stories of grandmothers who raise a family with only their culinary skills, some peddled their cooked food door-to-door - the food being cooked in their own kitchens.  My maternal grandmother is one.  I hope the Government would take a comprehensive look at all these aspects when they nurture a "silver" industry.

 

     Yes, a key plank has already been laid with the Minimum Sum in the CPF.  But in most cases, much as we can deliver the message of telling those in need to cut back on their lifestyle needs and curtail excessive expenses, many will be hard put also to live on $668 a month.  I also

Column: 244

read a paper that stated that a large proportion of the elderly live in households with only one breadwinner.  However, I have not seen enough data to feel good about as yet.  The medical and other expenses of supporting aged dependants would put a strain on singular breadwinners.  Hence, for those older people that are still prepared to work, to take off some burden from their immediate family members, we must find ways to help them out.  If the Government could put together a group of people to look into this, I know much can happen.  No group must miss out on the fruits of economic success.

 

     Then there is also a role for all Singaporeans.  Some weeks ago, a Filipino child wandered from her home and lost her way.  She found a guardian angel in the form of an old woman who sold tissue paper.  Her family was so grateful, they invited the old lady who was quite alone to spend some weeks with them.  The old lady was naturally delighted, and she took out the invitation readily to enjoy the warmth from a family for a while.  But her story pierced my heart, for it was a story of an old woman, a sad and sorry one.  Because she was all alone and missed the bustling prosperity of Singapore.  Need this old woman spend the end of her days in such loneliness and poverty?  And how many more old Singaporeans are in such stage out there?  Is there not more that we can do as a society to make all their lives a little better? 

 

     For the lonely elderly, the issue is not only about money for basic necessities.  Based on the latest figures available on the MCYS' website, 86% of the recipients of the Public Assistance Scheme are the aged destitutes.  There are 2,191 of them.  Under this scheme, a single adult household receives a monthly allowance of $260, two-adult household, $455. 

 

    But beyond the cash, as a community,

Column: 245

we must review our current systems of reaching out and caring for them, caring for these lonely elderly.  It has to be done on a consistent and sustainable basis.  Maybe an "Adopt-a-Grandma/Grandpa" programme could help integrate these lonely senior citizens back into our community.  They are in need of daily care and daily social support.  Should we just leave this task to the VWOs?  Or only to the Government?  Yes and no.  All of us have a role to play.  The VWOs and the Government can only facilitate the process.  But I believe the Government can do a lot more to pull Singaporeans together so that all Singaporeans, families and individuals can come forward and contribute.

 

     Mr Speaker, Sir, I have no doubt that our new leadership has the ability to lead all Singaporeans ably in the task of creating a Singapore to be a place for everyone.  Let us put our money where our mouth is and apply the resources to reach out to these Singaporeans who are "over by the window".

 

     With this, Sir, I support the motion.

Column: 246

     The various Ministries have also in the Addenda to the President's Address spelled out their policies and programmes in relation to the key priorities of the Government.  I look forward to further details on the respective implementation plans, the Budget Statement and its debate in February and March this year.

Column: 247

jobs.  But this year's projected investments are expected to bring in fewer new jobs, falling to 18,000.

 

     Nevertheless, it is important that the Government works with NTUC and its affiliated unions.  At this point, in fact, I would prefer that the President had mentioned in its Address about NTUC and its affiliated unions because, as trade union leaders, we are very proud of NTUC and its leadership, rather than just simply mentioning unions and employers. It was also mentioned in the Presidential Address, as I said, and stressed in the Ministry of Manpower's Addendum.  Yes, we must acknowledge the fact that the close tripartite partnership between the Government, employers and trade unions has been integral in our economic success.

     Another area of concern is employability beyond retirement age in view of longer life expectancy.  There is a need to focus our attention here on how to create opportunities or new avenues for the older workers in their 60s.  I agree that, together, we have to find new ways to safeguard their income security through enhancing their employability and improving their competitiveness.

 

     Mr Speaker, Sir, in the public sector, the workers in the civil service and statutory boards are feeling the impact of globalisation and its effects on their career prospects, including job security.  With the Government's aim of working towards a balanced budget, policies such as economy drive, waste management, management of manpower, the

Column: 248

framework itself and the other policies have inevitably caused some anxiety amongst them.  These policies must be explained and implemented with care and concern for the workers affected.  There should be early discussions and sharing of information between the unions and employers.  Both parties could then work out communication plans and manage the transition smoothly without causing much problems or trouble to the parties concerned.

     In effect, with lower employment (or even full employment) - we have to be optimistic, we should not say that we will never reach full employment again - during our economic recovery, I hope Singaporeans could lead a better life and have more to share with their families and friends.  This in turn will continue to foster community spirit, maintain racial

Column: 249

harmony and political stability in Singapore.  We all know these are necessary ingredients for attracting investments and economic growth.

 

     Mr Speaker, Sir, in summary, I would like to make the following observations with reference to the contents of the President's Address and its Addenda.  We must not, when implementing the planned programmes, overlook the middle-age workers' concerns and needs.  Our unionists would not hesitate to point out that this group of workers needs special attention, to help them remain employable in the global environment today.

1.6%; 20-29, 23.9%.  But if you look at those aged 30-39, who are on the way to the middle-age group, it was 28.7%,

and those in the 40-49 age group, 26.4%, and 50-59, 15.2%.  So I would say that easily 40% of this so-called middle age group are in this area, and we need to pay a bit more attention here because there is a tendency at times that we can go to extremes, with too much emphasis on the young and youthful, and the older people whom we have to look after, and we forget about those in the middle.

Column: 251

up its role and presence.  For example, Government's intervention would become necessary if employers do not take heed or cooperate at all.

     Dr Geh Min (Nominated Member): Mr Speaker, Sir, I thank you for the opportunity to support the motion to thank the President for his Address.

 

     In his Address, the President said that a key ingredient of our success has been our faith in Singapore.  I support this wholeheartedly.  May I also add that I believe that this is not a blind faith that he was talking about, but a faith that is based on mutual trust between an enlightened Government and enlightened citizens.  When I read sometime in October last year that Singapore had been ranked top in a survey conducted by the World Economic Forum on whether citizens trusted their governments, I

Column: 252

naturally felt very proud and privileged to be a Singaporean, and I still do.  But certain thoughts came to my mind. 

 

     Firstly, is it good for Singaporeans to have such near perfect trust in the Government?  Only 3% of Singaporeans said that they did not fully trust the Government, as opposed to most countries where more than 50% of their citizens said they did not trust their governments.  For surgeons, 97% is as perfect as you can get. 

 

     Secondly, it also occurred to me that though Singaporeans trust their Government, does the Government reciprocate this trust equally?  Clearly, an imbalance of trust can engender increasing apathy in its citizens.  If the Government is so trusted, what is there for Singaporeans to contribute?  To be fair to our Government, they have had the foresight to recognise the need for a more active citizenry, and organisations, such as the Feedback Unit, and committees, such as Singapore 21 and the Remaking of Singapore Committee, have addressed this issue.  Unlike the Member for Ang Mo Kio GRC, Mr Inderjit Singh, I have faith in what these initiatives achieve.  He said that they fizzled out.  I do not think they fizzled out.  They may not have galvanised the population into action straightaway, but I think the effect was, shall we say, more evolutionary rather than electrifying, and I believe that they made a big difference and are still making a big difference.

 

      So, the Government certainly deserves our trust.  Their long and outstanding, even awesome, record is very hard to match.  But I think Singaporeans have come a long way as well.  May I cite two examples.

 

     The first is the URA's public consultation on land use which was conducted in December 2000 as part of their Concept Plan review.  This is now

Column:253

recognised as a significant milestone in public consultation, both in the number of participants and agencies involved, and the openness of the process.  One of the five questions that URA posed to the public was:  "Would you prefer a larger living area or more parks and green areas?"  When I saw this question, I felt it was unfair.  I still feel it is unfair, because you are asking people to choose

between a material, measurable by personal benefit or gain against more parks and green spaces, which is a less quantifiable and common benefit. Surely human nature would, not just in Singapore but anywhere in the world, choose the first option. 

 

    However, I was very pleasantly surprised when I looked at the answers because a significant majority of Singaporeans chose the second, i.e., they chose more parks and green spaces over a more spacious living area. Many of them gave reasons. They said that in a land scarce country, it seemed fairer, more democratic, to share out the limited space rather than having their own individual living areas. They also said that a spacious living environment did not just mean more square metres to their flat because how many more square metres could they have:  A more spacious living environment could be the sensation of space that you would get when you look out of your window and see green and parks. 

 

    So to me, this URA exercise showed to me and I believe, to other people, that Singaporeans are not apathetic, that they can think of the common good rather than just their own immediate interest and that they can think out of the box.  About one-sixth of the people who responded also said:  why can we not have both?  Why can they not have more spacious living areas as well as green and parks?  So I felt that they did very well.  Obviously, this is a planned consultation exercise and

Column: 254

you might say that the respondents were self-selected and therefore not representative.

 

    Sir, I come to my second milestone, which is SARS.  The SARS crisis obviously took every one by surprise, Government and people.  No one had planned for it and this was a life-threatening crisis.  I would not go into details because many Members had already spoken about how both Singaporeans and Government came out very well with an enhanced mutual trust and respect for each other.

 

    But I would like to say that for me, one of the key factors why I consider this a milestone in Government-citizen relationships is that Government was transparent and communicative and open throughout the crisis. The then Minister for Health and the present Minister for Health and the PM and DPM, despite the stress and pressure that they were under during this crisis, gave daily press interviews.  And in these interviews, they did not just tell people that everything was all right.  They admitted to shortcomings and mistakes and they admitted to not knowing the answer at times. This, rather than eroding confidence in the Government, to me, inspired confidence amongst Singaporeans that our Government was honest, open, trustworthy, and in contrast to the many other countries where, I am sorry to say, there was a gap in credibility and sometimes even a breach of trust between Government and people.  I would not mention the tsunami disaster as a milestone because many people have already done so.  But clearly, it is another one which has brought us to an even further height of mutual trust.

 

    So through joint efforts of Government and citizens, we have reached a further level of public engagement.  This is certainly, I consider, a reason for congratulation but it is not an end-point. 

Column: 255

It is a step to even greater heights.  The Prime Minister, in a speech he made to the Harvard Club in January last year, said, "Looking ahead, one important task of the Government will be to promote further civic participation and to progressively widen the limits of openness."  Since giving this speech, he has already done much to widen the limits of openness.

 

    I would say, at this point, it appears to me that the logical next step to greater openness is greater access to information.  The Prime Minister also mentioned in the same speech that, and I quote, "The US has a very active citizenry, always ready to organise themselves and solve their own problems, without waiting for the Government."  In short, a proactive citizenry.  I should like to point out at this point that the US also has a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) which was created to allow citizens greater access to Government documents. Over 50 developed countries have a similar Act.

 

    I am not suggesting at this point that we adopt this.  I do not think Singaporeans either desire or feel the need to bring their Government to court in order to get information.  But I believe strongly that there is a connection between this acknowledgement of a citizen's right to information that bestows on him or her a sense of equality, a sense of pride, a sense of responsibility, which then engenders the desire to contribute to make a difference. 

 

     The Remaking Singapore Committee had many good recommendations.  One of them, I thought, was a Code of Consultation and I quote, "a public document providing guidelines and minimum standards of public consultation."  It then went on to recommend that certain areas and topics should be defined and also what information could be divulged. 

    

Column: 256

    I should like to suggest, at this point, that we push the limits of this Code further by adopting a green lane rather than a red lane approach to access of information.  Unless information is deemed potentially sensitive or likely to compromise security or religious or ethnic harmony or personal rights to privacy, it should go through the green lane.  By the way, I know everyone is expecting me to talk about green issues.  I think this is the only time I am going to mention "green" in my speech.

 

    Singaporeans, I believe, are mature and responsible enough to handle this access to information.  Any active citizen who had tried to have a constructive engagement with the public sector will sooner or later have encountered their tendency to press the "door close" rather than the "door open" button.  This is addressed by other Members of the House.

 

    I would admit, as others have, that their tendency to press the "door open" button is a lot more frequent now than it used to be and even if they press the "door close" button, they are more courteous about doing it.  And sometimes, they give you explanations before they do it.  And I would also say that there are many enlightened exceptions to this rule, including a couple of the Ministers who are here today and some senior civil servants, who have gone out of their way to press the "door open" button.  If everyone was like them, I would not be making the speech here.  But, unfortunately, they are still the exception rather than the rule. And the average citizen asking for information still feels that he or she is a practitioner, requesting for favours, taking up their time, rather than someone with equal rights to information.  The standards put down that we have all heard, whether in direct communication or in a reply from one of the Ministries in the Forum pages, is, "You represent an individual or a

Column: 257

narrow interest group.  Therefore, you cannot see the big picture (implication being of course that only Government can see the big picture)."

 

    I do not deny that our policy makers see a much bigger picture than we can or do.  But we would like to see the big picture too.  Most of us would like to see a big picture if we could.  However, as individuals or even groups such as NGOs, SMEs and VWOs, we lack the resources and the access to information to see the big picture. 

 

    May I add that no government can see the whole picture.  Even a Government like us, endowed with remarkable vision, will only see it from one perspective or miss certain details.  Our present and past PMs both have recognised and addressed this problem many times and called for change of mindset in the civil service and a more open and inclusive style of Government. 

 

    I should now like to talk about the label "narrow interest group".  May I say that naturally, when we advocate or petition for something, we have to be focused on the issue under discussion.  But the narrowness of the issue does not mean that we have tunnel vision.  For example, a nature lover is also a family member, a child, a parent, a spouse, he or she is also a breadwinner, worker, taxpayer, home-owner, consumer, commuter and even golfer, believe it or not, and above all, a Singaporean.  So, when we speak, we are speaking from all these perspectives combined.  No nature lover is going to push for conservation of a nature area if he or she thinks that it is going to endanger the future of his or her child. 

 

    I might add at this point that sometimes, when we speak to civil servants, we get a distinct impression,

Column: 258

whether correctly or not, that they seem to be speaking only as civil servants representing their particular Ministry.

 

     The challenges we face today make it important and even imperative that as many people as possible see the big picture and not just see it but contribute to it.  I may add that the picture is not a static one but something that is constantly evolving and changing.  We need both an enlightened Government and an enlightened public and to achieve this, we need to have more green lanes for the two-way flow of information.  Government, I would admit, is now very assiduous in collecting feedback. The Feedback Unit has done a very impressive job in this and so have various Ministries.  But while they are good at collecting information, it is still a bit slow in giving it out. Traffic is only free flowing in one direction most of the times, I am afraid. 

 

    While the President's Address and the Addenda effectively cover our future hopes and challenges, and spelt out some of the ways that we should meet them, I was disappointed at the insufficient emphasis on an integrated inter-agency approach.  True, this approach is mentioned by the President in relation to security and the terrorist threats, but not, for instance, in relation to sustainable development. 

 

    The economy, society and the environment - and I am not talking about the economic environment here, I am talking about the natural environment - have been separately addressed by the Economic Restructuring Committee, the Remaking Singapore Committee and the Singapore Green Plan 2012 respectively and by the relevant Ministries.

But there has been insufficient attention paid to the integration of these three initiatives.  For example, the Remaking Singapore Committee talks about active citizens but it never mentioned anything about active citizens contributing to the environment,

Column: 259

recycling, for example, which you could not achieve successfully without the contribution of citizens.

 

     The triple bottom line of sustainable developments requires that these three initiatives - the economy, society and environment - not be addressed as three separate pictures, but as one integrated picture.  And secondly, that the picture be constructed simultaneously, not sequentially, otherwise the window of opportunity may have closed by the time one decides to address it.  I am afraid here I have to mention the tsunami as an example, but I would mention the aspect which I think no one has addressed yet in the House.  As we read from reports, mangroves could have buffered some of the damages.  Warnings from meteorological officers about a potential earthquake and tsunami also were not heeded.  Because most of these countries, in fact, all these countries, were focused on economic progress.  So they missed the window of opportunity and, sad to say, it was tourism, the economy and, most of all, the people, the communities, who suffered.

 

     As a doctor and a nature-lover, I could appreciate how difficult it is to put information into the public domain, or even to share it with other agencies.  We, doctors and nature-lovers, are traditionally protective, even highly possessive, of our hard-gained, hard-earned knowledge.  Giving access to information entails taking risks, but we have to acknowledge the public's right to this information, whether we like it or not.  And that sharing of knowledge, while it may expose us to greater risks, would also give the whole society greater long-term benefits.  Chek Jawa, for instance, would never have been saved if nature-lovers had not revealed its treasure to the public.  I would venture to say that if Government and citizens had not reached such a level of mutual trust that we had, by the time Chek Jawa came up, we might not have

Column: 260

revealed it to Government, because we would not have seen the benefit of revealing.  We would just have appreciated it quietly, just a few people, and then it would have gone.  It would have become extinct without anyone else being the wiser or benefiting from the knowledge of the place. 

 

    Let me, therefore, in summary list some of the reasons why I believe that a greater pool of shared information and mutual trust are essential to our country.  Firstly, global competitiveness.  In a knowledge-based economy, disclosure of information and transparency are prerequisites in remaining competitive.  There are already some suggestions and signs that we may be lagging behind some of our global competitors, or would be, if we do not improve on these areas. 

 

     Secondly, global citizenship.  The President in his speech has emphasised that Singapore should be a bigger global player, not just in the economic arena, but as global citizens.  While we should not forgo Asian values, we should be sensitive and aware of the values of the global community and one of these is freedom of access to information.  We should, as global citizens, look at global as well as Asian values.      

 

     Thirdly, a greater sense of ownership and national identity.  As has been mentioned many times in this House, the Government recognises that younger Singaporeans have higher expectations than their parents and Singapore has given them wings and they could not wait to take flight.  Mr Gan in his speech mentioned kites.  I prefer the analogy of birds.  We want them to soar, to be global citizens, but we also hope that they would see their country not just as a jumping board or take-off point, but that they would regard Singapore as a home and come back to roost.  Why I prefer the analogy of birds to kites is that birds do not need to be tethered by a string.  They

Column: 261

could fly freely, but they do return.  Migratory birds may fly thousands of miles, but they come back to where they were born, their homeland, by choice.

 

    As global citizens, char kuay teow and childhood memories alone could not bring them back and, sad to say, sometimes, even family and friends could not tilt the balance.  I believe that only by feeling valued, trusted and challenged could we nurture and strengthen the sense of ownership and belonging in the younger generation and, in fact, in all Singaporeans.

 

     Fourthly, creating a buzz.  As our Prime Minister noted, bungee jumping and bar-top dancing are only surface forms of buzz.  Even the buzz of economic activity could not match the real buzz which I consider to be the buzz of ideas, knowledge and creativity.  If we wish to become an education, science and research, IT or arts centre, we must accelerate the exchange of information to generate this buzz of "talent, energy and vitality".

 

     Finally, facing future challenges.  I, again, quote our Prime Minister who said that, "To understand our challenges fully and vigorously, we need to draw on the expertise and resources of all our people."  To have an open and inclusive society, I believe we need better channels of communication and sharing of information.

 

     Mr Speaker, Sir, in the past, Government was proactive; Singaporeans were reactive and, often, inactive.  In the past, Government saw the big picture; Singaporeans only saw a small piece of it.  In the past, Singaporeans trusted their Government.  It was considered irrelevant whether the Government trusted Singaporeans.  Today, I believe it is important that both Government and 

Column: 262

citizens are proactive, could see the big picture, and trust each other equally.           

     The Minister, Prime Minister's Office (Mr Lim Boon Heng): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to support the motion.  What I am going to say would be in sharp contrast to what Dr Geh Min has spoken.  Mine would be fairly down-to-earth, to the constituency that I know best, which is the workers of Singapore.

 

     Our economy has been very volatile for the past seven years, since the Asian financial crises.  The swings in fortunes have led to many retrenchments.  While the manufacturing sector had constantly restructured over the past three decades, this time round the services and public sectors also restructured.  Significantly, many executives were also affected.  Those who lost their jobs had to make painful adjustments.

 

     Employees, therefore, feel insecure about jobs and income.  This sense of insecurity is only beginning to be assuaged as the economy recovers.  The news that employers are hiring, that unemployment has dropped, and that employers are paying higher bonuses, is slowly restoring confidence.  However, as some Members have spoken, the "feel good" factor is missing, and missing for those who lost their jobs.  Those who have found new jobs suffered big pay cuts.  Others have yet to find stable jobs, and are classified as a long-term unemployed, or structurally unemployed.  Even those who were not affected by retrenchments have been apprehensive.  Each retrenchment that is reported, especially in areas that previously seem secure, that seem to offer lifelong employment, renews this sense of insecurity.

 

     The truth is that we must expect greater volatility in the economy.  As global competition intensifies, we should expect to change jobs several times in our

Column: 263

working career.  Does this mean that we would be constantly on edge, feeling insecure?  How could employees regain their self-confidence in a more volatile economy?  How could they feel that Singapore is a land of opportunity?  If we have a social safety net that helps us through the economic cycles, then each of us would be self-confident.

 

     The key word is employability.  If an employee stays employable, he could move from one job to another.  It would not be a big problem to lose a job because he could find another one.  To stay employable, he must have the relevant skills.  Therefore, the answer is regular training and retraining.  Therefore, the first piece of a good social safety net would be the availability of training and the means of paying for such training.  We have put in place the framework for both.  I need not recount what we have.  However, we must not continue to think that training is the responsibility of the employer and/or the Government.  I think this is one piece which is still very much missing in the mindset of ourselves, that we think it is the responsibility of our employer to train or, if not the employer, then the Government.  I think we have to begin to think that it is our personal responsibility.  It is as much the responsibility of the individual for his own upgrading, as it is of either the employer or Government.

 

     How could we make the individual take responsibility for his training and retraining?  Mere exhortation would not go far.  One way is to establish individual learning accounts.  As the name implies, the funds could only be used for training.  This year, three cooperatives, linked with the NTUC, would start a pilot project.  Each employee would have an individual training account.  It would be real money, with co-contributions from employer and employee.  If the pilot programme works, then the concept could be adopted by other employers.  We are conscious that

Column: 264

other countries have tried, eg, the United Kingdom, and quickly closed it because of abuse.  That is why we think we should first start a pilot project, address all the issues, before suggesting it for wider application in our economy.    

 

     The second piece of the social security net would be funds for living expenses when an employee is in between jobs.  Today, employees rely on retrenchment benefits, but this is not reliable.  Some companies retrench when they are so broke that they could not pay retrenchment benefits.  A better way is to save for the rainy day.  Not everyone saves, when it is voluntary.  In most societies, the lower 40% of wage earners are unable to save.  If you look at our own statistics, our lower 40% do not have voluntary discretionary savings.  But we are not unique.  It is the same in the societies I have looked at.  As such, employees should be assisted to save.  Some employers have already programmes to help their employees to save.  We urge more to do so.  The same three NTUC cooperatives that are setting up individual learning accounts are also setting up individual savings accounts for their employees.

 

     The third piece of the social safety net would be cover for medical expenses, when one is unemployed.  The cost of outpatient treatment would not worry most people.  It is the cost of hospital treatment that is the concern.  Here, we already have a system that is centred on the employee - the Medisave and MediShield plans.  MediShield has degenerated and it now no longer fulfils its original objective of saving people from worrying about large hospital bills.  So a review is underway.  Mdm Halimah mentioned yesterday some of the desired outcomes of such a review. 

 

Each employee, armed with these three pieces of a social safety net, should therefore be able to face the volatile economy with greater confidence.

 

Column: 265

     But where are the jobs?  Both Members for Hong Kah GRC, Dr Amy Khor and Dr John Chen, were absolutely right when they said yesterday that the issue is still about jobs.  Job creation is a key priority of Government.  Jobs come from new investments.  Hence, we do all that we can to secure new investments, be it political stability, good infrastructure, a friendly tax regime or a flexible labour force.

 

     But are these jobs suitable for the long-term unemployed, many of whom have low skills?  We have to find them somewhere else, in existing jobs in the domestic services, for example.  We have had some successes in cleansing, in textiles, in patient care.  More can be done, and more must be done.  I am glad that some Members have urged that more be done.  For the NTUC, we target 10,000 such jobs in the coming year.

 

     Sir, there is a growing concern about financial security in retirement.  Often, our people are described as asset rich but cash poor.  Our compulsory savings system, the Central Provident Fund, is considered inadequate.  Some have surfaced the possibility of a pension system.  The proposal is for a limited pension.  But that is how most pensions started.  When the pension system developed in Europe, it worked like a dream.  Then more demands were put on the system and, today, pension systems the world over are in trouble  -  from Japan to the United States to Europe, all need serious revamp.

 

     On 1st June last year, the Business Times carried an article on this, and I quote:

 

     "Pension plan funding across the world is much like a dragon that has just begun to emerge from its cave.  Spurred by stock market

Column: 266

declines, poor investment plans, the beast is beginning to inflame the political process."

 

     Governments are doing two thing  -  raise the age of drawing down pensions, and cutting the pension pay-out.  Even Norway, that has put aside the revenue from its oil exports to fund pensions, finds it necessary to make changes because the oil revenues are enough for only a quarter of the pension liabilities.  The rest has to come from the people, meaning contributions and taxes.  So one proposal now is to raise the age when people can draw on the pension from 62 to 67.  We do not have oil to fund such a pension.

 

     Sir, some governments are taking a third step to supplement the trimmed down pensions with individual savings schemes similar to our CPF.  Sweden, the welfare state that is often quoted as the model state, implemented a compulsory contribution scheme.  The idea was to keep pension payments where they were.  If you cannot trim, then do not increase the liability of the fund  -  start individual savings accounts for the employees.  The experience is interesting.  Individuals were allowed to decide on how to invest their savings, something which sometime ago, many Singaporeans asked of their CPF.  By default, the state will invest the savings for those who did not choose to invest the funds themselves.  The result:  those who invested their savings which were, by and large, the upper end of the workforce, lost.  Those who left it to the state, gained.  I think the experience is quite similar to ours.

 

     Some countries have privatised pensions, be it company pensions or defined contribution plans.  A World Bank study has concluded that privatisation has not brought about the much vaunted benefits.  Private management of such funds is also subject to investment risks and poor management.  In most countries where retirement plans are privatised, the

Column: 267

participation rate is typically 20%.  So it did not cover the bulk of the workforce as intended.  Chile, another country where this has been held out as a model, has the best outcome but, even then, the participation rate is only 50%.

 

     Studying all the experiences of other countries has led me to the conclusion that the ideal of pension plans to fully fund the needs of retirees is not achievable for most people.  The old system of family support is still the most enduring.  Pension plans or CPF-type plans support the family to look after the elderly, to lighten the load, but cannot replace the family.  We should remember this and more of our policies should be aimed at keeping the family ties strong.

 

     Having said all that, since some countries with pension plans are moving towards CPF plans to supplement, should we supplement our CPF system with a limited pension plan, as some people suggest?  We, in a sense, already have such a plan in the annuity stream that we can draw on through the Minimum Sum.  So I think it is better to build on what we have than to try something new, and ending up with problems that other countries have encountered.  Why travel the road when we know the pitfalls that road leads us to?

 

     As people live longer, we should save more, if we can.  As I said, the truth is that for the lower income, it is difficult for them to save.  As they stay healthy, they can continue to work.  Today, as most MPs find, more and more of our senior citizens are looking for work and asking for help to find work.

 

     When we looked at the labour force participation rate, we were disappointed that many people below the age of 62 are not working.  Our effective retirement age is therefore well below 62.  It is the same for many OECD countries, but some countries stand out with effective

Column: 268

retirement ages above the official retirement age.  How did they do so?  Japan is one such country.  Those of us who travelled to Japan over the years, as Mr Wee Siew Kim obviously has done, would have noticed that the people who man the highway toll booths are senior citizens, though they are now being replaced by automated systems.  Mr Wee Siew Kim mentioned about the traffic light controllers.  Sometimes, when we visit Japan, we encounter, say, road works and there is a need for a temporary set of lights, and the people who man the temporary light system are senior citizens.  In Singapore, they are foreign workers.

 

     So, I asked myself, was there a national consensus in Japan, as they discussed raising their retirement age, to 'reserve' some jobs for older workers?  Should we have such a national consensus?  Retrieving the luggage trolleys at Changi Airport is being done by senior citizens.  I do not know whether it is the policy of the CAAS to do so, but I think that is a good example of what we have in Singapore.  This is something that can be done.  It is a job that can be done satisfactorily by older workers.  We need not waste the energy of young people to do that same job.

 

     Sir, what other jobs should be reserved for older workers?  Pump attendants at petrol kiosks?  Guides at our museums?  If we want to raise the effective retirement age, then we need to forge a national consensus to provide the older workers with job opportunities.  Then, we will be truly an inclusive society, with opportunities for everyone.

 

     Mdm Cynthia Phua (Aljunied): Mr Speaker, Sir, I speak in support of the Motion of Thanks to the President.

 

     In his speech to this House, the President had said that we open this Second Session of the Tenth Parliament with a heavy heart.  Sir, it is important

Column: 269

that we be mindful of the fragility of the material world and the vulnerability of mankind, as we look back at the events that left many parts of Southeast Asia devastated by the tsunami.  It is indeed unfortunate that we have to end 2004 with such a painful souvenir of human tragedy.

 

     But there was one good cause that came out of this calamity, ie, it brought the people in the region closer together.  Today, we are ever closer to the people of Indonesia, Sri Lanka, Thailand and Malaysia.  We are, as the President had said, a member of the global community, closely linked to share their joys and their sufferings.

 

     Our response to the disaster was swift and decisive.  The whole machinery went into action  -  the military, the medical team and the humanitarian aid.  It heartens me to see so many Singaporeans, especially the young, channelling their energies to good use when the nation needed them most.  This army of young volunteers, some with parents and grandparents in tow, came forth to volunteer their services to collect donations, pack the foodstuff, clothes and other items for shipment to the neighbouring countries.

 

Investing in our young

 

     This brings me to the point that I want to make today  -  investing in our young  -  in that we need to constantly imbue in our young the right values so that they know that the prosperity and peace of today can always be washed away tomorrow without warning.  They have to be prepared for the life of constant effort, of labour and strife, which is the very foundation on which our forefathers had built up our nation.  While I do not suggest that we limn a picture of our past and etch them on the walls of public

Column: 270

buildings and exhibition walls, I certainly feel that we can do more to remind our young so that they better appreciate the very difficult footsteps taken by our forefathers.

 

     While I feel that we have made some inroads in engaging our youths in the field of arts and sports, and in giving them some space to channel their creativity and their energies, I believe there are many youths out there who need direction in life.  There are many who lack the inner spiritual and physical strength to shed their cloistered life, and are waiting to be shown how they can be drawn to make a meaningful contribution to our society.  That our youths are easily drawn to western fad, such as to tattoo their bodies like the way cowboys brand their cattle on the hind side, and for them to be so easily drawn into a frenzy and into almost blind adulation of an idol, beg the question:  what is going on

in the minds of these young people?

 

Education

 

     The second concern is education.  While national service has done much good for the young, this education to give our youths the courage to face strenuous life should begin when they are still in school.  The Ministry of Education has expanded the CCA.  I feel that more needs to be done so that character building and ruggedness are also imbued in the activities, so that we do not breed a society of lily-livered boys and girls.  Since we just won the Tiger Cup, let me take soccer as an example.  A player may learn from his coach the rules and the techniques of the game.  He may also learn about his responsibility to his team mates, and his club.  But will a coach teach him his responsibility as a sportsman?  That a robust play may be appropriate but this is provided it does not cause undue injury to his opponent.  That just as there must be humility in victory, there must also be acquiescence in
